Award.AwardTitle: Exploring Growth Mechanisms of Nonequilibrium Nanostructured Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This project supports theoretical and computational research on the study of novel materials growth mechanisms and the integration with education and outreach activities. An important phenomenon during the materials growth or fabrication process is the formation and evolution of structures at the nanoscale, which plays a pivotal role in controlling material properties that are of fundamental and technological importance. This research addresses a fundamental challenge of understanding and predicting the growth and self-assembly of nanostructured materials, particularly how to effectively tackle the complexity of the systems which are far from the tranquil state of equilibrium and require a description that can span a wide range of length scales and include interconnected processes across length scales. The PI will develop predictive modeling methods and conduct theoretical analyses and computer simulations to investigate the growth and dynamics of novel nanostructures that emerge from these processes, and predict new types of modulated structures in thin films under various material growth or processing conditions.

This project supports the training and education of graduate students, and involves the PI's broader education efforts for the research community through lecture development for summer schools and workshops. This project incorporates the PI's outreach activities for STEM education in an all-girls minority public school in Detroit. The activities include the instruction and support of high-school student science projects and the training of Wayne State education undergraduates, to enhance the K-12 STEM education for young women who are underrepresented minority students and the professional development of both pre-service and in-service science teachers.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This project supports theoretical and computational research integrated with education to provide a systematic study on the growth and dynamics of nonequilibrium nanostructured materials. The research addresses a fundamental challenge of understanding and predicting the growth mechanisms underlying the nanostructure assembly in functional material systems, particularly for systems that are out of equilibrium and governed by effects of coupling among different spatial scales that control material microstructures and dynamics. This research focuses on the exploration of novel nanostructures that are both morphologically and compositionally modulated, through three parts of investigation: (i) the development of modeling approaches based on the phase field crystal method and amplitude formalism, which can bridge mesoscopic and microscopic scales and incorporate system elasticity and plasticity, (ii) the study of nanostructure formation and dynamics during material heteroepitaxy, particularly for strained quantum dots modulated by nanoscale compositional patterns or eutectic microstructures, and (iii) the investigation of coupling mechanisms at meso and micro scales, for the coupling between morphological and compositional meso-scale instabilities and the coupling between meso and micro scales determining different growth modes. Comprehensive studies will be conducted numerically and analytically to identify various material growth mechanisms and the growth conditions for achieving controllable and coherent nanostructures, and predict new types of modulated structures in heteroepitaxial systems. The overall objective of this research is to advance our understanding of both structural and compositional dynamics in nonequilibrium and nanostructured material systems. This project also integrates the efforts of graduate and undergraduate education, and outreach activities designed for pre-service and in-service science teachers and their high-school students' science projects, to enhance K-12 science education for young women in Detroit who are underrepresented minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has supported a theoretical and computational research program for the study of structures and dynamics of nonequilibrium material systems, particularly the formation and evolution of novel nanostructures and ordered patterns and the corresponding elastic and plastic behaviors of topological defects such as grain boundaries and dislocations, which are of both fundamental and technological importance in materials growth, assembly, and processing. The research was conducted through the development of advanced multiple-scale modeling methods, as well as systematic theoretical analyses and large-scale computation and simulations.

Large progress has been made on the development of novel modeling methodology across microscopic and mesoscopic scales. This involves various aspects of continuum density-field approaches based on the phase field crystal (PFC) type models, which have the capability of accessing large system sizes and realistic time scales that are not accessible to traditional atomistic approaches, while still maintaining microscopic spatial resolution. In this project our newly developed methods include (1) a full density-field formulation integrating interparticle length and orientation control and system rotational invariance, (2) a binary PFC model with sublattice ordering to describe the structures and dynamics of two-component materials, (3) a general approach to calculate the elastic constants of stressed and unstressed materials in continuum field modeling like PFC, (4) a new and efficient PFC model to incorporate the vapor-liquid-solid phase coexistence and transitions and some important material properties within a single continuum field description, (5) a continuum statistical description of active matter that can simultaneously capture effects of particle self-propulsion and self-spinning and the active crystallization process, as well as (6) new method and computational scheme for the PFC and amplitude models to obtain fast elastic relaxation and plastic deformation dynamics that can overcome the limitation of previous continuum density-field approaches.

The above methods developed in this project play an important role on revealing the structural and dynamical insights of a broad range of solid, soft-matter, and active systems, as demonstrated in our research. We have applied these methods and models to investigate and predict a variety of material phenomena, properties, and the underlying mechanisms. These include (i) the control of various two-dimensional (2D) and three-dimensional crystalline phases, (ii) the emergence of binary 2D ordered or quasi-ordered structures and superlattices in two-component colloidal systems and the related structural transformation, (iii) the new behavior of jerky plasticity and brittle-to-ductile transition during the mechanical response of grain boundaries in graphene, (iv) the grain rotation dynamics in 2D binary hexagonal materials like h-BN showing novel effects of the lattice inversion symmetry breaking on the motion of dislocations and grain boundaries, and (v) the prediction of novel, persistently dynamical states in spatially ordered, out-of-equilibrium active systems that are driven by a new mechanism governing the self-rotation and self-flow of active crystallites. (vi) We have also identified and predicted the structural (packing and percolation) and electrical transport properties of nanoparticle composites of metal-insulator spherocylinders, through the implementation of particle-based simulation methods for jammed random packing and electrical percolation. All these research outcomes have contributed to our further understandings, and can stimulate further experimental and theoretical studies, in this technologically important area of materials synthesis and processing.

This project has integrated our research efforts with the education, training, and professional development of two graduate and two undergraduate students. It included an outreach program to promote K-12 STEM education in the Detroit area serving female underrepresented minority students. The outreach activities have been conducted in the Detroit International Academy for Young Women (DIA), an all-girls minority public school, to bring enhancement of science education to the students there through the collaboration with a science teacher in DIA and the participation of two Wayne State undergraduates. This has benefitted the DIA students for their scientific learning and knowledge improvement, the Wayne State undergraduates for their gaining of authentic teaching experience, and the science teacher of DIA in terms of much-needed help and enhancement of teaching and student instructing.
